title: July 2012 FQE - Paper 1 (Clinical Scenarios)
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics Paper 1 (July 2012). Focuses on Clinical Scenarios and Management.

questions.question: CASE STUDY: Joseph (2 years old) presents with 2 weeks of swollen feet, peeling skin ('flaky paint'), refusal to feed, and loose stools. Exam: Apathetic, Weight 6.5 kg. Select the correct diagnosis and Day 1 management steps.

richContent.content:
Patient: Joseph, 2yo.
Signs: Edema, Dermatosis, Apathy, Severe Wasting (6.5kg).

options.text: Prevent Hypoglycemia: Give 10% Glucose or F-75 immediately

questions.explanation: This is Kwashiorkor. Immediate steps (Day 1): Hypoglycemia/Hypothermia prevention, Rehydration with ReSoMal (low sodium), Antibiotics (infection often masked). Iron is contraindicated in stabilization phase.
questions.hint: Edema + Peeling skin = Kwashiorkor. NO Iron initially.

questions.question: CASE STUDY: Baby Margaret (14 days old) presents with refusal to feed, mild jaundice, and jerking movements. Temp 38.2Â°C. Select the likely differentials and correct management.

richContent.content:
Patient: Neonate (14 days).
Presentation: Fever, Seizures (jerking), Jaundice, Poor feeding.

questions.explanation: Symptoms suggest Sepsis/Meningitis or Bilirubin Encephalopathy. Management: Admission, IV Antibiotics, Anticonvulsants (Phenobarbitone), and Phototherapy.
questions.hint: Fever + Seizures in a neonate = Sepsis/Meningitis until proven otherwise.

questions.question: In a child presenting with cough, vomiting, and diarrhea, which specific physical examination signs are crucial to assess?

options.text: Hydration: Sunken eyes, skin pinch, fontanelle

questions.explanation: Key exams focus on severity: Respiratory distress signs (pneumonia?) and Hydration status (diarrhea). AVPU assesses shock/meningitis.
questions.hint: Focus on the ABCs and hydration status.

questions.question: A 1-year-old (10kg) presents with Severe Dehydration. Select the correct management plan (Plan C).

options.text: Fluid: IV Ringer's Lactate or Normal Saline
Rate: 30ml/kg in 1 hour, then 70ml/kg in 5 hours
Rate: 30ml/kg in 30 mins, then 70ml/kg in 2.5 hours
Follow-up: Oral Rehydration Solution and Zinc

questions.explanation: For an infant (<12 months), Plan C is 30ml/kg in 1 hr + 70ml/kg in 5 hrs. For a child (>12 months), it's faster (30 mins + 2.5 hrs). The question says '1 year old' - technically an infant schedule is safer or on the border, but often treated as infant in exams if exactly 12 months.
questions.hint: Infant rate is slower (6 hours total).

questions.question: A child has Rheumatic Fever with Arthritis and Carditis (no cardiomegaly). Select the appropriate treatment steps.
questions.explanation: Bed rest and Penicillin are standard. For Carditis, steroids (Prednisolone) are often indicated, though some guidelines use Aspirin for mild carditis. Digoxin is for heart failure (cardiomegaly), which is absent here.
questions.hint: Steroids are used when the heart is involved.

questions.question: Mbiyu (6 months, 8kg) has 10 watery stools, vomiting, lethargy, and sunken eyes. What is the classification and immediate treatment?
questions.explanation: Lethargy is a danger sign indicating Severe Dehydration. Immediate IV resuscitation is required.

questions.question: John (6 months) has poor feeding, vomiting, bulging fontanelle, fever, and stiff neck. Select the correct diagnosis and management.
questions.explanation: Bulging fontanelle + Stiff neck + Fever = Meningitis. Requires LP, IV Antibiotics, and Steroids.
questions.hint: Bulging fontanelle indicates raised intracranial pressure due to infection.

questions.question: A 6-year-old has difficulty breathing and wheezing that worsens at night. History of eczema. Select the correct diagnosis and acute treatment.
questions.explanation: History of eczema + nocturnal wheeze suggests Asthma. Acute management: Bronchodilators and Steroids.

questions.question: A 4-year-old presents with a painless abdominal swelling on the left side. Which features suggest Wilms Tumor?

options.text: Mass does not cross the midline

questions.explanation: Wilms Tumor typically does NOT cross the midline (unlike Neuroblastoma). It is usually painless.
questions.hint: Renal tumors stay on their side initially.

questions.question: Kezia (5yo) presents with fever, joint pains, pallor, jaundice, and splenomegaly. She has had previous transfusions. Select the diagnosis and management.

options.text: Management: Apply cold packs to joints

questions.explanation: Sickle Cell Vaso-occlusive crisis with Hemolysis. Treat with Fluids, Painkillers, Antibiotics. Cold is contraindicated.
